chargeHist.descr: Soliciting a person to practice prostitution

result.execSummary:
The defendant Kevin K. Kayhart was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Solicitation of Prostitutes [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 944.32.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Conditions of extended supervision are the same as the conditions of Probation
Defendant to report to Probation and Parole immediately

miscConds.notes: Defendant is ordered to have a sex offender assessment and follow all recommendations, releasing all records to the agent.  Defendant is ordered to  have a psychological evaluation and follow all recommendations, releasing all records to the agent.   The defendant is ordered to participate in any Counseling  as deemed appropriate by the agent releasing all records to the agent.

Defendant is to abstain from the consumption of any alcohol and not go into places that sell alcohol except incidentally such as a grocery store, convenience store or gas station or other such place where alcohol is not sold for consumption on the premises.  The defendant shall have no contact with the victim Tabitha Podevels of any kind, including in person, in writing, by phone,by e-mail, or through a third party.

The defendant shall pay Department of Correction fees as directed by the agent.  The defendant shall submit to random urine testing as required by the agent .  Defendant is ordered to provide a DNA sample for testing through the Dept. of Corrections as required in felony convictions.

timeConds.notes: Defendant was granted 164 days credit for time served.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Kevin K. Kayhart
